Sights
Restraunts
Shops
Info
The Cascade Combining water and lighting effects this landmark is a spectacular series of fountains, which is especially eye-catching at night. 5800 Pleven Centre
Mausoleum St. Georgi Pobedonosets Built in honor of the fallen soldiers during the siege of Pleven in 1877-1878, which remains are buried in this chapel. Pleven Centre, Vazrajdane No.5 Square
Regional Historical Museum Originally built for military purposes, today the museum contains 10000 tomes of scientific literature, and numerous objects of historical value, some dating back to the Roman Empire . Stojan Zaimov No.3 Street
Maika Bulgaria Memorial At the entrance of Scobelev park, you can find this monument depicting a woman overlooking the whole city atop a huge flight of stairs. It is built for the 100th anniversary of the Bulgarian liberation. Alexander Scobelev Street
Scobelev Park Built in 1904 in honor of the fallen russian and romanian soldiers during the siege of Pleven. It is located on the battlefield, south of the city. 5804 Pleven
"Plevenska Epopeja 1877" With its symbolical architectural structure, a huge realistic frieze on the top floor depicting the battlefield, and a rich historical gallery, this spectacular landmark is a must see in Pleven. Scobelev park
Kailaka Park Located south from the center of the city, the park has numerous restaurants and a zoo. With its rich natural flora this park has a fresh atmosphere, perfect for walks,cycling and other sports. 5800 Kailaka
Storgozia Fortress This historical land site was built by the romans between 5th-6th century. The building once was 3-4 story high and occupied around 30000 square metres of land. Kailaka Forest 35
Museum Tsar Osvoboditel Aleksandar II Built by the wealthy merchant Ivan Vatsov, this house has turned in to a park-museum. 5800 Pleven Centre

Public Transport If you need a cheap and efficient way to travel around Pleven, you would want to consider using trolleys, which are the main public transport unit. Tickets are really cheap and should take you to most parts of town.
Plan your trip Keep in mind that Pleven is a relatively small town, and one week should be more than enough to visit more notable landmarks in the city.
Seasons in Pleven The weather can be erratic sometimes during the spring seasons, and winter is very cold here. Check weather forecasts regularly if you decide to visit.
Counterfeit items You could get scammed with counterfeit items by smugglers if you are not careful. So remember if it sounds too good to be true, it usually is not.
Pleven (Bulgarian: Плевен pronounced [ˈplɛvɛn]) is the seventh most populous city in Bulgaria. Located in the northern part of the country, it is the administrative centre of Pleven Province, as well as of the subordinate Pleven municipality. It is the biggest economic center in Northwestern Bulgaria. At the end of 2015 its population is 99,628. Internationally known for the Siege of Plevna of 1877, it is today a major economic centre of the Bulgarian Northwest and Central North and the third largest city of Northern Bulgaria after Varna and Rousse. Pleven is located in an agricultural region in the very heart of the Danubian Plain, the historical region of Moesia, surrounded by low limestone hills, the Pleven Heights.The city (then mostly known as Plevna outside Bulgaria) was a major battle scene during the Russo-Turkish War of 1877–1878 that Russian Tsar Alexander II held for the purpose of the liberation of Bulgaria. The joint Russian and Romanian army paid dearly for the victory, but it paved the path to the defeat of the Ottoman Empire in this war, the restoration of Bulgaria as a state and the independence of Romania from the Ottoman Empire. It cost the Russians and Romanians 5 months and 38,000 casualties to take the town after four assaults, in what was one of the decisive battles of the war. The siege is remembered as a landmark victory of the Romanian War of Independence, as on 28 November 1877 the Plevna citadel capitulated, and Osman Pasha surrendered the city, the garrison and his sword to the Romanian Colonel Mihail Cerchez.
